<years>before 1377 – circa 1414</years><paragraph>Otto III von Bergow was a notable Czech nobleman of Thuringian-Meissen origin who held royal offices at the provincial court and served as the burgrave of Prague from 1388 to 1393. Later, as a leading member of the League of Lords, he served on the royal council, where he actively opposed his king, Wenceslas IV. During Wenceslas IV's imprisonment in Vienna, Otto held the position of the highest provincial chamberlain, a post entrusted to him by the Hungarian king Sigismund of Luxembourg. In this role, he was responsible for tasks such as collecting taxes from royal towns and certain monasteries or approving appointed councilors.</paragraph><paragraph>Otto's original domain included Biela (Bílina) and Seeberg (Žeberk) in northern Bohemia, which he sold to purchase the Rohozec estate and Trosky Castle, which he extensively rebuilt. After Wenceslas IV returned to the Czech throne, he was removed from his offices and died in 1414.</paragraph>

<years>1377年前 - 约1414年</years><paragraph>奥托三世·冯·波尔高出身于图灵根和迈森家庭，是一位名声显赫的捷克贵族，在省部法庭任王室职务。1388至1393年间，他曾任布拉格城伯，后来又以贵族联盟中领导成员的身份，在皇家议会中任职，期间竭力与国王瓦茨拉夫四世针锋相对。瓦茨拉夫四世被囚禁于维也纳期间，在匈牙利国王西格斯蒙德的委任下，奥托担任最高省府总管一职，职权包括向皇室村镇或修道院收取税款，或任命准议员等。</paragraph><paragraph>奥托最初管辖的领地包括北波希米亚的比耶拉（Bílina）和泽贝格（Zeberk），后又被他出手转售，随即购买了罗霍泽茨庄园和特罗斯基城堡，还进行了大规模的重建。瓦茨拉夫四世重夺捷克王位后，奥托三世即被撤职，后于1414年逝世。</paragraph>

<years>1388(?) - 1419</years><paragraph><accent>young Lord Capon (Jan Ptáček) </accent></paragraph><paragraph>Son of Ješek Ptáček and Hedvika of Duba. After the death of his father, Jan Ješek, the Lords of Leipa (uncle Henry, his son Hanush and his brothers) became his guardians.</paragraph><paragraph>After the imprisonment of Master Jan Hus, he signed a petition in his defence. In the Hussite wars, however, he initially sided with the League of Lords against the Hussites in a few minor battles (in 1419 he took part in the battle against the Hussites at Knin), apparently due to the influence of his close neighbour Lacek of Kravař from Šternberk. There are no records indicating he took part in the war later.</paragraph><paragraph>He was the Lord of Rattay and Polná. He acquired Rattay from his guardians only in 1412. He held positions in the provincial offices and his son was the famous Hynek Ptáček.</paragraph><paragraph>Unlike his historical precursor, however, we took the poetic license of making Hans Capon a twenty-year-old man in our game.</paragraph>

<years>1388（?） – 1419年</years><paragraph><accent>卡蓬少主</accent></paragraph><paragraph>耶舍克·卡蓬和道巴的海德薇卡之子。在卡蓬父亲死后，莱佩众领主（亨利叔叔、其子瀚纳什与其弟兄）均成了他的监护人。</paragraph><paragraph>在扬·胡斯入狱后，他签署了保护胡斯的请愿。不过胡斯战争刚爆发时，他选择站在了领主联盟一方，一同对抗胡斯运动成员，还参与了几场小战役（1419年，他在科宁参加了对抗胡斯派的战争），这显然是因为受到了他的近邻，斯滕堡（sternberk）的克拉瓦尔的拉切克（Lacek of Kravar）的影响。但并没有资料能证明他参与了后来的战争。</paragraph><paragraph>他曾是拉泰和伯尔纳（Polná）的领主，只是在1412年他才从他的监护人手中接过拉泰。他还担任过省部官职，且其子便是名声远扬的海尼克·卡蓬。</paragraph><paragraph>然而，在我们的游戏中，我们大胆地让卡蓬先生比他的真实原型年长，并将他设定为二十岁的男子。</paragraph>

<paragraph>The first mention of the Cimburk (Zimburg) family dates back to 1142, when an alleged ancestor of the family, Miroslav, founded Sedletz Monastery - the oldest Cistercian abbey in Bohemia. His origins are unknown and the coat of arms, of silver and red battlements, is only documented on a seal from the 14th century.</paragraph><paragraph>The original family seat is unknown, but according to legend the Cimburk family themselves considered it to be a castle above the Vrchlitz valley near Poličany. However, research here has only documented a nameless prehistoric and early medieval hillfort. Two other castles of the same name were founded by the family during the 14th century in Trnávka and near Koryčany in Moravia.</paragraph><paragraph>Notable members of the family were the brothers <accent>Jan Balšán</accent>(Posy) and <accent>Miroslav</accent> of Cimburk, who got into a dispute over their inheritance with their uncle Aleš (Alesh). They became infamous as robber knights and mercenaries during the Hussite Wars.</paragraph>

<paragraph>有关齐姆博格家族的记载最早可追溯到1142年，据称当时该家族中一位名为米洛斯拉夫的先祖，建立了塞德莱茨修道院——波希米亚最古老的熙笃会修道院。而那位祖先的出身不为人知，至于他们的家族纹章——银红相间的城垛——只在14世纪的印章上有所反映。</paragraph><paragraph>齐姆博格家族的起源地至今不详。据家族成员传说，坐落在波利恰尼（Policany）附近弗赫利茨谷地之上的一座城堡，就是他们的家族起源地。然而，相关研究表明，该地仅发现了一座建于中世纪早期的史前无名堡垒。14世纪时，齐姆博格家族修建了两座同名的城堡，分别位于摩拉维亚地区的特尔纳夫卡（Trnávka）和科里恰尼（Korycany）附近。</paragraph><paragraph>著名家族成员有<accent>扬·贝桑（Jan Balsán）</accent>(即“花骨朵”）和<accent>米洛斯拉夫</accent>（即“扯骨”）两兄弟。他们曾因继承问题与叔父阿莱什（Ales）发生争执，后在胡斯战争期间，成为了臭名昭著的强盗骑士与佣兵。</paragraph>

<paragraph>One of the most famous and controversial figures in Czech history. The man who became the face of the Hussite uprising.</paragraph><paragraph>Unfortunately, only the last six years of his life are thoroughly documented. We know that he lost an eye in his youth and that in 1408, Zizka served in the sabotage unit of a certain Matthew the Leader and made a living as a bandit in the service of various nobles. According to some leading Czech historians, the activities of his band had more of a political than a material character.</paragraph><paragraph>From existing records, we know that when he was later arrested and sentenced, King Wenceslas IV granted him a pardon. There is a theory that at least part of his activities might have been carried out at the behest of someone from the king's entourage.</paragraph><paragraph>His most famous historical period follows the outbreak of the Hussite uprising when he took command of the rebel forces and earned a reputation as a brilliant strategist and an undefeated military leader who led the Hussites from victory to victory.</paragraph>

<paragraph>捷克历史上最具争议的著名人物之一，此人亦是胡斯起义的代表人物。</paragraph><paragraph>遗憾的是，只有他生平的最后六年得到了详细记录。我们目前知道他年轻时失去了一只眼的视力。而在1408年，杰式卡在某个名为“领导者马修”的蛮横组织内服役，以强盗的身份与各路贵族打交道为生。根据一些捷克著名历史学家的说法，他的强盗团伙活动与其说是为了抢劫财物，不如说更具有政治意义。</paragraph><paragraph>我们根据现存记录得知，他后来被逮捕并判刑时，国王瓦茨拉夫四世赦免了他。有一种论调认为，他的部分行为可能是在国王手下某位随从的指示下进行的。</paragraph><paragraph>他最为人所知的历史时期是在胡斯起义爆发之后，当时的他接管了叛军的指挥，以杰出的谋略而声名远扬，并且他作为一位未尝败绩的军事领袖，带领着胡斯派取得了一场又一场的胜利。</paragraph>

<paragraph>In Kuttenberg, as in other towns of the time, it was not the nobility who ruled, but rather the wealthy townsmen, known as <italic>patricians</italic>. The total wealth of the patrician families of Kuttenberg is estimated to be the second largest in the kingdom, second only to the wealth of the burghers in the capital city of Prague.</paragraph><paragraph>The most prominent family was the <accent>Ruthards</accent> with the Maleshov fortress and several parish churches, followed by the <accent>Píseks</accent> with fortresses in Kouřimsko and Suchdol, the <accent>Adlers</accent>, and the <accent>Vorsuchers</accent>.</paragraph><paragraph>These families lost their power during the Hussite wars, when they had to flee the town to the countryside and lost some of their properties. The exception was the Adler family, who managed to regain their properties after the war.</paragraph>

<paragraph>库滕堡与当时的其它城镇一样，它的治理者并非贵族，而是被称为<italic>patricians</italic>（上流阶级）的富裕市民。据估计，库滕堡此类群体的家族财富排名王国第二，仅次于首都布拉格的市民。</paragraph><paragraph>其中最显赫的家族就是坐拥马列索夫堡垒和几座教区教堂的<accent>鲁瑟德家族</accent>，其次是在库里姆斯科（Kourimsko）和苏赫多尔拥有堡垒的<accent>皮塞克家族</accent>，还有<accent>阿德勒家族</accent>以及<accent>沃苏查家族</accent>。</paragraph><paragraph>但在胡斯战争期间，这些家族失去了自身权势，不得不从城镇逃往乡村，还失去了部分财产。但阿德勒家族却是个例外，他们在战后还成功夺回了他们的财产。</paragraph>

<years>1354/5 - 24 September 1405</years><paragraph>Prokop of Luxembourg, son of John Henry of Luxembourg, was a provincial governor of the kingdom and Margrave of Moravia from 1375 to 1405. Together with his brother Jobst, he was to rule Moravia, but most of the time they fought disputes over succession of the Luxembourg dynasty, which had ambitions to win the Polish and Hungarian crowns.</paragraph><paragraph>After the death of Charles IV, he initially supported the policies of Sigismund of Luxembourg and fought against Wenceslas in the <italic>Margraviate Wars</italic>. But after the Bohemian nobility imprisoned Wenceslas, he became his ally. </paragraph><paragraph>第一位是来自<accent>库斯塔特与波迪布拉德家族的博舌克</accent>，此人为摩拉维亚贵族。我们已知，查理四世于1353年，授予博舌克“最受喜爱者”和“皇家斟酒官”的称号。除了坐拥波迪布拉德家族名下以及位于摩拉维亚的大量资产外，博舌克还在布拉格拥有一座富丽堂皇的房屋，这座房屋也被国王免除了所有税费。后来，因奥布尔尼（Obrany）一座未竣工的城堡，他与查理四世的兄弟、摩拉维亚侯爵约翰·亨利发生冲突。而后又在国王的干预下，他不得不拆除城堡，并与侯爵和解。1371年，他接管了利蒂茨的一座重要城堡。</paragraph><paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_barber<paragraph>Wherever hygiene, and thus baths were lacking, public baths became popular. Public baths in Central Europe appeared from about the 12th century. Every town had them, often in significant numbers. Sometimes a town would have three to four bathhouses.</paragraph><paragraph>Here, people had access to hot water for bathing or steam baths. In those times, steam was produced by pouring water onto heated iron or stones. Body cleanliness was taken care of by male and female bath attendants. Overall body washing was done in bath tubs, coopered wooden vats and tanks.</paragraph><paragraph>In Bohemia, there were baths in operation since the early Middle Ages and their numbers rose steadily. There were 47 public baths in Prague in the second half of the 14th century and by the 15th century the baths were attended not just by the well-to-do, but also by the poorer classes. There was even a regulation that the bath-keepers had to open their doors once a quarter to the poor and to students.</paragraph><paragraph>Bathhouses typically belonged to the municipality, and were leased to the bath-keepers. In addition to municipal and private baths, there were also private baths in the houses of the nobility and wealthy townspeople.</paragraph><paragraph></paragraph><paragraph>In the 13th and 14th century, the bath-houses were very much associated with prostitution. In the 13th century particularly, bath-house prostitution became widespread and there were scarcely any that did not provide sexual services. In the richer urban baths there would also be pharmacists, masseurs, stokers and cleaners. In the villages the bath-house keeper had to do all these jobs himself.</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_bojova_technika<paragraph>In the High Middle Ages, new elements of combat techniques and weapons and armour emerged. Curved sabres became popular, and chainmail was replaced by plate armour. Knights preferred heavier swords, crossbows, and impact weapons such as maces and flails.</paragraph><paragraph>Only wealthy nobles could afford full armour. Usually, only partial metal armour was worn, and more than for protection, the focus was on combat technique.</paragraph><paragraph>For this reason, swordfighting developed in two ways: </paragraph><paragraph>a) <accent>knightly swordsmanship</accent> – fighting with a spear, sword, and shield in full heavy armour</paragraph><paragraph>b) <accent>common swordsmanship</accent> – for lightly armoured fighters who fought with swords and common weapons such as falchions, flails, scythes, staffs, etc.</paragraph><paragraph>In battles between lightly armoured and heavily armoured fighters, speed, agility, and cleverness often won. Therefore, swordplay also interested the poorer parts of society. They gradually started to be educated in swordfighting schools. The training was not very professional, being based more on dexterity, readiness, and the use of various available means besides weapons.</paragraph><paragraph>Precise contemporary descriptions of duels are lacking, so historians rely on mentions in literature or preserved visual material.</paragraph><paragraph>中世纪兴盛时期，出现了各种新式武器、盔甲和格斗技巧。弯马刀变得很受欢迎，板甲也替代了链甲。骑士们选用更重的长剑、弩和打击武器，例如钉头槌和连枷等等。</paragraph><paragraph>只有富有的贵族才能买得起全套盔甲，更多的人只买得起部分部件，然后依赖优秀的战斗技巧防身。 </paragraph><paragraph>因此，剑术发展出了两个流派： </paragraph><paragraph>a）<accent>骑士剑术</accent>——适用于全副武装的骑士，使用长矛、剑盾战斗，并且装备全套盔甲。 </paragraph><paragraph>b）<accent>一般剑术</accent>——适用于轻装步兵，使用剑和自制武器战斗，例如砍刀、连枷、镰刀和短棒。 </paragraph><paragraph>在轻甲战士和重甲战士之间的战斗中，通常是速度、灵活性和聪明才智起决定性作用，因此贫民阶层也开始对剑术产生兴趣。后来，他们开始在剑术学校中学习技巧。那里的训练并不专业，更强调的是灵敏度和利用手边一切除武器外的可用资源。</paragraph><paragraph>当代缺乏精确的有关战斗的记录，因此历史学家们只能依靠文献中的描述或保留下来的插画来研究。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_brabantskevevodstvi<paragraph>The Duchy of Brabant was a geopolitical county, located in the historic Netherlands, on the territory between the rivers Zenne and Dender.</paragraph><paragraph>Its founding was decided in 1183, by Frederick I Barbarossa, the Holy Roman Emperor at the time. He elevated Count Henry I of Brabant, to the position of Duke of the Brabant Landgraviate. This political decision was intended to resolve the administrative confusion with the imperial fiefdom, that had arisen after the death of the previous Count of Brabant, Hermann II.</paragraph><paragraph>In 1430, Philip III the Good, inherited the duchy, which became part of the Burgundian Netherlands, along with Limburg and Lower Lotharingia, and then from 1482, part of the Habsburg Netherlands.</paragraph><paragraph></paragraph><paragraph>At the end of the 16th century, the <accent>Dutch Revolt</accent> brought about the division of the territory of the Duchy of Brabant between the Netherlands and Belgium.</paragraph><paragraph>布拉班特公国是位于历史上荷兰地区的一个地缘政治县，位于塞纳河和登德尔河之间的领土上。</paragraph><paragraph>1183年，当时的神圣罗马皇帝腓特烈一世·巴巴罗萨决定创立布拉班特公国。他提拔布拉班特的亨利一世伯爵，将其封为布拉班特地伯公爵。这一政治决定旨在解决前任布拉班特伯爵赫尔曼二世去世后，帝国封地所引发的行政混乱。</paragraph><paragraph>1430年，腓力三世继承了布拉班特公国，使其成为勃艮第荷兰的一部分，包括林堡和下洛塔林吉亚，并且从1482年起成为哈布斯堡荷兰的一部分。</paragraph><paragraph>16世纪末，<accent>荷兰起义</accent>导致了布拉班特公国领土分裂，分成荷兰和比利时两部分。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_castles<paragraph>Early Gothic buildings in Bohemia were inspired by France and the Rhineland. Among the earliest were the monastery in Předklášteří near Tišnov, South Moravia, the chapter house in Osek, North Bohemia, the monastery of St Agnes in Prague and many parish churches and monasteries such as those in Kolin and Kouřim in Central Bohemia.</paragraph><paragraph>At the turn of the 13th and 14th centuries, Czech architecture diverged from its western counterparts. There was a burgeoning of Cistercian monasteries, e.g. in Zlatá Koruna and Vyšší Brod in South Bohemia, and churches and castles, e.g. Bezděz, North Bohemia. The <accent>High Gothic</accent> period was ushered in during the time of Charles IV and Wenceslas IV, with its rectangular windows and portals, rayonnant traceries and quadripartite, sexpartite, or cross-ribbed vaulting.</paragraph><paragraph>The most significant buildings of that time include Charles University, St Vitus Cathedral, Charles Bridge, Prague Old Town Hall and New Town Hall, stone houses in Prague and the castles of Karlštejn, Kost and Kašperk.</paragraph><paragraph>Records of <accent>construction work</accent> fellowships first appear during this time: the most famous are those of Master Peter Parler and his family, and Matthias of Arras, who also worked on the reconstruction of Sasau Monastery.</paragraph><paragraph>New castles no longer served just a defensive function, but were also intended to serve as royal residences. They were therefore more spacious and elaborate and had extensive gardens.</paragraph><paragraph>波希米亚早期的哥特式建筑的灵感来源于法国和莱茵兰。其中最早的建筑，是南摩拉维亚的提什诺夫（Tisnov）附近的普莱德克拉斯特里（Predklásterí）修道院、北波希米亚的奥赛克的牧师会礼堂、布拉格的圣阿格尼丝修道院，以及很多位于中波希米亚的教区教堂和修道院，例如那些的科林和库日姆（Kourim）等地的建筑。</paragraph><paragraph>在13世纪至14世纪之交，捷克的建筑风格开始与西方分野。在南波希米亚的泽拉塔克鲁纳（Zlatá Koruna）和维希布罗德（Vyssí Brod）等地区，熙笃会修道院如雨后春笋般崛起，北波希米亚的贝兹德兹（Bezděz）等地区的教堂和城堡亦是如此。查理四世和瓦茨拉夫四世在位期间迎来<accent>哥特盛期</accent>，该时期典型建筑设有矩形的窗户和立面、辐射式的窗花格，以及四分、六分或交叉式的拱顶。</paragraph><paragraph>此时期极具意义的建筑有查理大学、圣维特大教堂、查理大桥、布拉格老市政厅和新市政厅及其他石质建筑、卡尔斯坦因城堡（Karlstejn）、科斯特城堡（Kost）、卡斯佩克城堡（Kasperk）等。</paragraph><paragraph>关于建筑工团体的最早记录中，最著名的是彼得·帕勒大师及其家族，还有阿拉斯的马蒂亚斯，后者也曾参与过莎邵修道院的重建工作。</paragraph><paragraph>新城堡不仅被用作防御工事，还是皇室居所，因此被修建得更加宽敞和精美，还配有大型花园。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_certi<paragraph>Demons (Chorts) are mythical and fairy-tale inhabitants of hell specific to Slavic cultural context. While in the rest of Europe people refer to demonic creatures as devils and attribute purely negative intentions to them, in Czech folklore we lean towards the image of demons as mischievous, malicious, and often foolish beings depicted with goat horns, a tail, and hooves on their feet, subservient to the will of the ruler of hell, Lucifer.</paragraph><paragraph>Medieval magical thinking attributed various qualities to demons. Many a castle had a notorious gate to hell in its basement, many a mill or abandoned building served as their abode. Demons smelled bad, caused disturbances, and were blamed for hens not laying eggs, milk souring, and food spoiling.</paragraph><paragraph>While the church refuted other originally pagan beliefs, it assimilated demons for its purposes, portraying them as tempters and punishment for believers who weren't devout.</paragraph><paragraph>恶魔（Chorts）是神话和童话中居住在地狱的生物，是斯拉夫文化背景下特有的。虽然在欧洲其他地方，人们将恶魔生物称为魔鬼，并将纯粹的负面意图归咎于它们，但在捷克民间传说中倾向于将恶魔描绘成恶作剧、恶毒且时常愚蠢的生物。它们长有山羊角、尾巴，蹄子，遵从地狱统治者路西法的意志。</paragraph><paragraph>中世纪与魔法世界有关的观念为恶魔赋予了各种特质。人们会认为许多城堡的地下室中设有通往地狱的入口，因此而臭名昭著；许多磨坊或废弃建筑物则被认为是恶魔的盘踞之地。恶魔气味难闻，能够引发骚乱，还会被认为是母鸡不下蛋、牛奶发酸和食物变质的罪魁祸首。</paragraph><paragraph>尽管教会排斥其它源自异教的信仰内容，但还是出于自身用途把恶魔纳入了文化体系中，将它们描绘成诱惑之源以及作为不虔诚信徒的惩罚。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_certovka<paragraph>The Devil's Den is still today one of the smallest settlements in the Kuttenberg region. Unfortunately, no records of its appearance in 1403 have survived, but in the 16th century, the infamous <accent>Devil's tavern</accent> stood on its site, where the lowlifes of Kuttenberg often gathered, and which served as a model for our Devil's Den.</paragraph><paragraph>The name of the settlement and the tavern comes from a legend, according to which, devils were said to come out of the local mines and fly over Kuttenberg at midnight. They were only driven from their dens by water, which later flooded the mines.</paragraph><paragraph>We also learn about the dark character of the former inn from the memoirs of Mikuláš Dačický: 'Michal', a messenger of the mining authority, killed the innkeeper Št'astný with a spear in the Devil's tavern near Kuttenberg, where there was a den of rogues and whores. They were fighting over some gloves.'</paragraph><paragraph>“魔窟”至今依然是库滕堡地区规模最小的居民点。遗憾的是，关于1403年时它出现的记录没有留存下来，但在16世纪，臭名昭著的<accent>“恶魔酒馆”</accent>当时就建在它的位置上，库滕堡的不良分子经常聚集于此，酒馆的存在也为我们的“魔窟”提供了参考。</paragraph><paragraph>这个居民点和酒馆的名字源自于一则传说。据说当地的矿场有恶魔出没，它们会在午夜时分飞过库滕堡。恶魔们被水从洞穴内驱赶而出，后来水也将矿场淹没。</paragraph><paragraph>我们还从米库拉什·达希克（Mikulás Dacický）的回忆录中了解到了这家旅馆灰暗的历史：“矿业官员的信使米卡尔用矛杀死了库滕堡附近‘魔鬼酒馆’的店主斯塔斯特尼（st'astný）。那家酒馆就是流氓和妓女的窝点，他们甚至会因为一些手套而产生争斗。”</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_cesky_raj<paragraph>An area, also known as <accent>Bohemian Paradise</accent>, about 90 km north-east of Prague with a great number of natural and cultural monuments. The main landmarks of the region are Kozákov Mountain and <accent>Trosky Castle</accent>, while other important sites include, for example, the Prachov and Klokoči rock formations, the castles Kost, Waldstein and Sychrov, and a number of ponds.</paragraph><paragraph>Its picturesque landscape is mainly underscored by the ubiquitous sandstone rocks, characterised by their steep and rugged reliefs and towers.</paragraph><paragraph>It is an important protected landscape area and a popular destination for climbers. Nowadays the area is crisscrossed with a dense network of tourist trails, making it a haven for nature lovers and enthusiasts of historical landmarks.</paragraph><paragraph>In the medieval period the region was quite bustling, particularly due to the numerous castles, fortresses and fortifications, which are located almost literally on every hilltop.</paragraph><paragraph>位于布拉格东北约90公里的地方，有一个被称为<accent>波希米亚乐园</accent>的地区，那里拥有大量自然和文化古迹。该地区的主要地标就有科扎科夫山（Kozákov Mountain）和<accent>特罗斯基城堡</accent>，其他著名景点还包括普拉霍夫和克洛科奇岩石群（Prachov and Klokoci rock formations）、科斯特城堡、瓦尔德斯坦城堡、西赫罗夫城堡以及多处池塘。</paragraph><paragraph>那里风景如画，砂岩随处可见，以其崎岖、峻峭、塔状林立为特色。</paragraph><paragraph>这里是一处重要的景观保护区，也吸引着大批攀岩爱好者。如今，这处自然和古迹爱好者的天堂，纵横交织着密集的游览线路。</paragraph><paragraph>中世纪时期，这片地区格外繁华，尤其是数不胜数的城堡、堡垒以及防御工事，几乎每座山丘上都能看到它们耸立的身影。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_cimburk<paragraph>Settlement in the area dates back to the late Stone Age (about 3000 BC). Today, however, only traces of an early medieval fortified settlement remain in the form of remnants of moats and visible ramparts.</paragraph><paragraph>Some historians (as well as folk legends) claim that Zimburg (Cimburk) Castle, owned by the <accent>Lords of Zimburg</accent>, once stood here and was even perhaps their ancestral home. Later, the descendants of the family built two more castles with the same name: Cimburk in Trnávka and Nový Cimburk in Koryčany.</paragraph><paragraph>Unfortunately nothing remains from the original castle. Hence why some historians claim that such a castle never stood here and the settlement rather got its name from the nearby mine that belonged to the Zimburg family. Nevertheless, we decided to depict it in the game.</paragraph><paragraph>与该地区有关的人类定居史可追溯至后石器时代（大约公元前3000年）。然而，如今此地仅存一处中世纪早期的防御性居住点的遗迹，而遗迹的结构也仅剩沟壕和可见的城垛。</paragraph><paragraph>一些历史学家（以及民间传言）声称，由<accent>齐姆博格领主</accent>持有的齐姆博格（Cimburk）城堡曾伫立于此，而且据说它还可能是领主们祖先的家。后来，家族的后人们又增建了两座城堡，同样以相同的名字为其命名，分别是：特尔纳夫卡（Trnávka）的齐姆博格城堡以及科里恰尼（Korycany）的新齐姆博格城堡。</paragraph><paragraph>遗憾的是，原始城堡早已不复存在。因此，才有一些历史学家认为此处从未有过居住点的存在，而所谓居住点的名称可能取自附近齐姆博格家族名下的矿场。但无论如何，我们还是决定在游戏中向大家展示这座城堡。</paragraph> 有些扰乱公众秩序的罪犯会被绑在镇上广场的颈手枷中示众，对于罪犯来说，这样相当于荣誉尽丧，家族也会背上恶名，这要比嘲笑和蔑视糟糕得多。</paragraph><paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_fashion<paragraph>Clothing for villagers and common folk had to be comfortable, durable and practical. It consisted of a simple shirt and a tunic. Men also wore <italic>braies</italic> (knee-length linen drawers). In winter they wore hooded cloaks, furs and hats. All typically in natural colours without embellishments. The exception was <accent>festive attire</accent> for special occasions and religious holidays.</paragraph><paragraph>In the city, clothing reflected status, wealth, but also affiliation to a particular group, such as craftsmen, soldiers or apprentices. Belts, bags, gloves, hats and other headgear were used as accessories.</paragraph><heading>Hairstyles</heading><paragraph><accent>Unwed young women</accent> had long hair, which they wore down or in braids. Women in towns adorned their hair with ribbons, pearls, wreaths and vines. Older <accent>married women</accent> wore pearled nets on their heads, white or coloured veils or hats. Fashionable <accent>men</accent> had long, coiffured hair, they liked to shave their chins and wear various headwear.</paragraph><heading>Jewellery</heading><paragraph>Jewellery was fashioned from gems, wood, leather and metals. The most common types of jewellery were <accent>earrings</accent>, various types of crosses and, in the High Middle Ages, <accent>rings</accent>, which were both representative and symbolic. Floral and animal themes as well as figural motifs inspired by religious themes predominated in decoration.</paragraph><heading>Footwear</heading><paragraph>Shoes were made of leather, but also of grass, straw, bast, wood, cloth or felt. In the countryside, people often went barefoot in summertime. <accent>Soles</accent> (left and right) on shoes first appeared in the mid 14th century while heels were added in the 15th century.The most common type of footwear consisted of sandals and slippers made of wood or cork. Stitched shoes were called either <italic>škrpály</italic> (low shoes) or <italic>škorně</italic> (above the ankle).</paragraph><paragraph>对村民和其他平民来说，服装最首要的是舒适、结实和实用，通常多是些简单的衬衫和短袍。男人也会穿着及膝的<italic>亚麻裤</italic>，冬天时还会穿兜帽斗篷、皮外套和帽子。大部分服装都是自然朴素的颜色，没有装饰。为了宗教假日和特殊庆祝场合准备的<accent>节庆服装</accent>则是例外。</paragraph><paragraph>在镇上，服装能够反映穿着者的社会地位、财富状况，当然还反映了特有的身份，例如工匠、士兵或学徒。配饰包含腰带、袋子、手套、帽子和其他头罩等。</paragraph><heading>发型</heading><paragraph><accent>未婚女子</accent>留披肩长发或是编成辫子。镇上的女人会用丝带、珍珠、花环和藤蔓装饰头发。年长的<accent>已婚女子</accent>会在头上戴珍珠网，白色或彩色的面纱，或者帽子。时髦的<accent>男人</accent>会留长发并做成发型，他们还会剃须，穿戴各式各样的头饰。</paragraph><heading>珠宝</heading><paragraph>珠宝首饰由宝石、木头、皮革和金属制成。最常见的首饰为<accent>耳环</accent>、各种各样的十字架，以及在中世纪兴盛时期流行的<accent>戒指</accent>，当时的戒指既可以代表身份，又具有象征意义。首饰上的装饰图案主要是花朵和动物，以及受宗教主题启发的人物形象。</paragraph><heading>鞋子</heading><paragraph>当时的鞋子由皮革制成，也有些用青草、稻草、树皮、木头、布或者毛毡制成。每到夏天，乡下人经常光脚出行。区分左右脚的<accent>鞋底</accent>首次出现于14世纪中期，而鞋跟则出现于15世纪时。最常见的鞋子有木质或软木的凉鞋和拖鞋。缝制的鞋子包括<italic>skrpály</italic>（低帮）和<italic>skorně</italic>（高帮）两种。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_food<paragraph>In the Middle Ages, both in villages and at royal courts, primarily <accent>locally available foods</accent> were used. Vegetables included cabbage, onions, parsnips, turnips, beets, garlic, with smaller quantities of carrots, celery, parsley, cucumbers and melons. Legumes such as peas, lentils, vetch and broad beans were common, alongside fruits like apples, pears, cherries, plums, berries, nuts, seeds and grains. Eggs, milk and cheeses were available year-round.</paragraph><paragraph>Depending on wealth, availability and the season, <accent>meat</accent> (game, poultry, fish) and imported goods like spices, fruits and delicacies such as saffron, dates, figs, nutmeg, pepper, sugar, ginger and cardamom were also consumed. Meals were seasoned with oils, vinegar, salt, honey and herbs.</paragraph><paragraph>The most popular dishes in the 14th and 15th centuries, especially in rural areas, were hearty soups, thickened porridges, and sauces served with bread. Rye bread was common, while white bread was reserved for the court. Meat was expensive, and hunting in forests (reserved for nobles) was prohibited, so fish often compensated for its scarcity.</paragraph><paragraph>During a <accent>lavish feast</accent>, dishes with fish like pike, various roasted meats, sausages, minced meat, black pudding and legumes were essential. Desserts included almonds, marzipan, sweet porridges with fruit cooked in milk or with added cream, jams, baked, raw and dried fruits, and assorted pastries.</paragraph><paragraph>In the Middle Ages, many of today's common ingredients were unavailable, such as potatoes, tomatoes, corn, peppers, rice or beans, which generally arrived in Europe only after the discovery of the Americas or through Asian imports.</paragraph><paragraph>中世纪时期，无论是村庄还是在皇室，粮食一般都来源于当地，蔬菜主要是白菜、洋葱、欧防风、萝卜、甜菜和大蒜，有时会有红萝卜、块根芹、西芹、黄瓜和各种甜瓜；豆类有豌豆、扁豆、野豌豆和大豆；水果有苹果、梨、樱桃、李子和和梅子。此外，还有浆果、干果、种子和谷物。鸡蛋，牛奶和奶酪一年四季都有供应。根据富裕程度、供应量和季节不同，可能还会有肉（兽肉、家禽、鱼类）和进口的调味品、水果和香料，包括干藏红花、枣、无花果、肉豆蔻、辣椒、姜和小豆蔻。食物通常用油、醋、盐、蜂蜜和草药调味。</paragraph><paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_grunta<paragraph>The village was founded by miners sometime in the mid-13th century, when silver ore began to be mined in the area. In the 1270s, according to records, 300 miners and their families were already permanently settled on the nearby Kuklík hill. Legends say that when King Přemysl Otakar II of Bohemia went to battle and needed horses for his army, he took 500 of them from Kuklík alone, which interrupted mining for a while and the miners had to leave.</paragraph><paragraph>Under Wenceslas II, new silver veins were discovered, which attracted new miners. The village began to expand and the German name for it became <italic>'Grunt in Mariae'</italic> (Valley or Mine of the Virgin Mary, abbreviated to Grunta in Czech). In addition to residential houses, infrastructure for processing the extracted ore also began to appear, as well as facilities for sorting, crushing or smelting. The waste from mining was enormous, so the remaining tailings and slag began to be exported around the area and new landforms were created.</paragraph><paragraph>In the village there is also the Church of the Visitation of the Virgin Mary. Already in records from 1305 it is written that it was delapidated, so it is not surprising that in 1367 a new church was built by local miners and townspeople of Kuttenberg.</paragraph><paragraph>The mining and smelting premises operated here intermittently until the 15th century, when silver reserves were almost exhausted (it is estimated that 80% of the ore was mined here in less than three centuries).</paragraph><paragraph>13世纪中叶，这片区域开始出现银矿开采活动，因此矿工们便建立了这座村庄。据史料记载，13世纪70年代期间，当时已有300位矿工及其家人永久定居在了附近的库克里克（Kuklík）山丘。有传闻称，带兵征战的波希米亚国王奥托卡二世急需马匹，因此便从库克里克取走了500匹马，这也导致了采矿作业的中断，矿工们不得不因此离开。</paragraph><paragraph>瓦茨拉夫二世执政期间，新的银矿资源被发现，这为矿工队伍引入了新鲜血液。随后，这座村庄开始扩展，德国人将其称为<italic>“Grunt in Mariae”</italic>（圣母玛利亚之谷或矿场，捷克语缩写为Grunta）。除了住宅外，村里开始出现用于加工矿石的基础设施，以及一些用作分选、粉碎或冶炼的设备。当时采矿产生的废料庞大，剩余的尾矿和矿渣被引至周围地区，因此形成了全新地貌。</paragraph><paragraph>村中还有为“圣母访亲节”而造的教堂。早在1305年的记录中就表明了它已破败不堪，因此当地矿工与库滕堡市民们于1367年再修建了一座新教堂便也不足为奇。</paragraph><paragraph>这里的采矿与冶炼设施直至15世纪时都在断断续续地运作着，而当时的银矿储量已几乎枯竭（据估计，仅在三个世纪内，此地80%的银矿就已被采掘而出）。</paragraph> <paragraph>在波希米亚王国，火器在胡斯战争期间变得举足轻重。有趣的是，胡斯派对早期火器的命名产生了影响，并传播到世界各地。例如，英语中最轻的手持火器<italic>pistol</italic>一词源于捷克语<italic>pístala</italic>，原意为烟斗或笛子。</paragraph> <paragraph>将火药倒入枪管，用填料密封，然后放入弹丸，最后用夯杆夯实。使用燃烧的导火索或加热的铁片通过触孔点燃火药。早期的火器非常不精确，射程也很短，只有几十米，但即使在这个距离上，它们也能击穿坚固的装甲。</paragraph> <paragraph>另一种在欧洲中部受欢迎的手持火器则是钩枪。它有一根口径约为20毫米至30毫米的铜质或者铁质枪管，装在一根木制枪托上。 类似pístala一样，但它枪口下面带有一个钩子，能让武器射击时可以架在墙，栏杆或者战车的边缘之上来显著减少开火时沉重的后坐力。</paragraph> <paragraph>围攻城市或城堡时，则会使用更大更重的火器，如各种各样的火炮。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_gunpowder<paragraph>Black powder is the oldest known explosive, discovered around the 9th century in China. Initially, it was used in medicine and widely experimented with by alchemists. However, when it failed to yield the anticipated elixir of immortality, its powerful explosive properties began to be used for ammunition production. It likely arrived in Europe as early as the 13th century, although some experts believe that Europeans discovered black powder independently of China.</paragraph><paragraph>The European inventor of gunpowder is typically attributed to either the German alchemist Berthold "The Black" Schwarz, or, according to other sources, the German friar Albertus Magnus, who was familiar with the recipe for gunpowder as early as 1275. Another mention can be found in the work of the alchemist Marcus Graecus, who included a black powder recipe in his writings around 1300. However, at this time, gunpowder was not yet commonly used in combat.</paragraph><paragraph>Originally, a fine particle mixture known as “meal powder,” produced by grinding the individual components, was used for shooting. Later, methods were developed to produce larger grains, which significantly improved the consistency of ballistic properties and accuracy in shooting.</paragraph><paragraph>黑火药是目前已知最古老的炸药，大约在9世纪由中国人发明。黑火药最初被用于医疗领域，且广泛地用于炼丹师的实验当中。显然，黑火药并没能如同预期般地成为长生不老药，但那之后人们利用它的爆炸特性将其用于弹药生产中。黑火药可能早在13世纪便已传入欧洲，也有一些专家声称欧洲人是独立发现黑火药的。</paragraph><paragraph>欧洲火药的发明者通常被认为是德国炼金术士贝索德·施瓦茨。也有一些其他的说法，比如德国修士阿尔伯特·麦格努斯，据说他早在1275年就掌握了火药配方。也有关于炼金术师马库斯·格拉厄库斯的记载，他在大约1300年的著作之中收录了一份黑火药的配方。不过，在那段时间，火药还并未广泛用于战争之中。</paragraph><paragraph>最初人们使用的火药是一种研磨而成的，称为“粉末火药”的细颗粒混合物，通常用于射击。之后人们研发出了生产较大颗粒火药的方法，大大提高了其弹道性能、射击精度和稳定性。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_havir<paragraph>While in the medieval quarries the hard work was done by rock cutters and stone masons, in the mines skilled labourers - <accent>miners</accent> worked for wages. It was tough work. Using only hammers and chisels (these tools are depicted on the first Kuttenberg coat of arms) and by the light of small hand-held lamps, did they extract the valuable ore.</paragraph><paragraph>Mining in the rock was slow, but thanks to perseverance and shift work, they eventually dug underground tunnels reaching hundreds of metres (sometimes up to 450m). This created larger and more passable horizontal and vertical shafts - underground pits - from which smaller galleries ran out in chains, where miners had to literally crawl on all fours. Safe movement in such conditions was ensured by unique, durable clothing, the most essential parts of which were a leather apron and knee pads.</paragraph><paragraph>The arduous and prolonged work was expedited by a method called <italic>fire setting</italic>. A fire was set at the end of the shaft, cracking the rock, and making it easier to chip away. Even so, mining was dangerous and exhausting, and miners' wives often became widows many times over.</paragraph><paragraph>Every miner was thoroughly searched after his shift, because the silver belonged to the king and there were severe penalties for theft. Still, they did occur, for as the age-old saying goes: 'The brazen miners have work till Saturday, but coin only till Sunday.'</paragraph><paragraph>在中世纪的采石场中，当凿岩工和石匠还在为艰苦劳作而汗流浃背之时，矿洞里的熟练工人，即，<accent>矿工</accent>，早已为丰厚报酬干得热火朝天。采矿是项艰辛的工作，人们只能使用锤子和凿子（这些工具曾是库滕堡第一个市徽的图案），手持煤油灯，在微弱的灯光下采掘有价值的矿石。</paragraph><paragraph>在岩石中进行采矿是一项效率缓慢的工作，但由于坚持不懈和轮班工作的实行，他们最终得以掘出数百米长（有时长达450米）的地下隧道。如此便造出了更宽敞、更易通行的水平和垂直矿井，也就是地下矿坑，而小型连锁矿廊因此得以延申而出。矿工们在这些小型矿廊中移动时必须匍匐前进，为保证安全，他们需要穿戴特殊、耐用的衣物，其中最重要的便是皮围裙与护膝。</paragraph><paragraph>一种名为<italic>“点火采掘”</italic>的采矿技术的出现，让费力且耗时的采矿工作效率大幅提升。人们在矿井末端燃火，将岩石炸裂，进而降低了开凿的难度。但尽管如此，采矿依然是项危险且劳累的工作。因此，许多矿工的妻子最后都成了寡妇，而且不止一次。</paragraph><paragraph>因开采而出的银矿归皇室所有，为防止盗窃银矿，每位矿工下班前都要受到详尽的搜查。即使如此，银矿盗窃事件依然会发生，因此就产生了一句古老的谚语：“高傲的矿工在山中辛劳至周六，但工钱周日就花光。”</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_horany<paragraph>The settlement on the border of the Kolin and Kuttenberg regions was likely inhabited since ancient times. In the 1970s, a borehole discovered a prehistoric granary with remains of pottery of the so-called Knovíz culture (8th-6th century BC).</paragraph><paragraph>Regarding preserved records, Horschan is mentioned in 1299, when Wenceslas II handed it over to the Sedletz monastery and Markvart Šik of Kuttenberg. In 1437, Sigismund of Luxembourg (by then already Emperor) pledged the village to the 'Hussite King', George of Podiebrad.</paragraph><paragraph>科林与库滕堡交界处的定居点可能自古就有人居住。20世纪70年代，人们在钻井时发现了一间史前谷仓，里边蕴藏着被称为克诺维兹（Knovíz）文化的陶器残骸（公元前8世纪至公元前6世纪）。</paragraph><paragraph>根据已存记录可知，霍斯昌于1299年被史料提及，当时瓦茨拉夫二世将其给了塞德莱茨修道院以及库滕堡的马科瓦尔·塞克（Markvart sik）。1437年，卢森堡的西格斯蒙德（当时已称王）将村庄许诺给了“胡斯国王”波德布拉多（Poděbrady）的乔治。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_inquisition<paragraph>The Inquisition (from Latin <italic>inquisitio</italic> - to search, to inquire) was founded in the 12th century as a response to the massive heretical movement of the Albigensians (Cathars). Originally it was intended to serve more as a tool to punish and direct the clergy, but later its main mission became the fight against all the heretics. It was directly subordinate to the Pope, and thus became more or less an independent power.</paragraph><paragraph>The Inquisition had <accent>three main tasks</accent> - to search for heretics; to interrogate them and convict or bring them to repentance; and to refer the unrepentant to the secular authorities for punishment.</paragraph><paragraph>The incoming inquisitor first reported to the local bishop and then had a solemn mass and sermon celebrated. He then received reports (denunciations) of heresy from the local people. Heretics were given a so-called <italic>period of mercy</italic> in which they could declare themselves and ask for forgiveness. The inquisitor evaluated the reasonings and began his own process, which was more intended to confirm the accusations, rather than objectively examine them.</paragraph><paragraph>Although in the common consciousness, the Inquisition is mainly associated with cruel practices, fanatical actions and a great fear of inquisitors, one of the intentions of the Inquisition and its operation, was to rationalize and legalize the trial of heretics and to suppress the practice of <italic>ordeals</italic> - <accent>Divine trials</accent>.</paragraph><paragraph>The Inquisition process was thus based primarily on the testimony and interrogation of the accused. The accused, however, had almost no rights and could be subjected to torture. The Inquisitorial trial was conducted in secret, but the proceedings were recorded in writing for the needs of the Inquisition. These records were intended to prevent manipulation of testimonies.</paragraph><paragraph>宗教法庭（其名源自拉丁词汇<italic>inquisitio</italic>，意为“搜索”、“询问”）成立于12世纪，只为应对阿比尔派教徒（天主教加尔派）的大规模异教运动。起初，宗教法庭是负责惩罚和指导神职人员的工具，但后来其主要职责转变为打击所有的异端教派。宗教法庭由教皇直接管辖，因此在某种程度上成为了一个独立的权力机构。</paragraph><paragraph>宗教法庭拥有<accent>三大主要职责</accent>：搜捕异端者、审讯异端者，以及判定其罪责或引导其忏悔；对于不愿忏悔之人，法庭还会将其交给俗世权力机构进行惩罚。</paragraph><paragraph>新任的法官首先要向当地主教汇报，随之举行庄严的弥撒和布道，而后即可接收当地平民对异教人士的举报（公开告发）。遭告发的异端者被给予所谓的<italic>“宽恕期”</italic>，在此期间，他可以自首并请求宽恕。法官在评估罪人的说辞后便会启动相关程序，但更多是为了确认指控，而非客观地审查罪人。</paragraph><paragraph>尽管在大众的观念中，残酷执法、激进行事以及令人恐惧的法官是宗教法庭带给人们的印象，但宗教法庭的运作及其行事目的之一是为了将对异教的审判合法、合理化，并压制<italic>“神圣审判”</italic>（也称为<accent>“神判”</accent>）的现实效益。</paragraph><paragraph>因此，宗教法庭的审理过程主要基于被告的证词和审讯。然而，被告人几乎没有任何权利，并且可能还会遭受酷刑。宗教法庭的审讯通常秘密进行，但是会根据需要进行笔录，而这些记录的意义是为了防止证词篡改。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_jan_sokol<years>cca. 1355 – 28 September 1410</years><paragraph>Jan Sokol of Lamberg was a military leader, provincial governor, son of Jaroslav of Kninice, and a friend of Radzig Kobyla.</paragraph><paragraph>He actively participated in the internal disputes of the Luxembourg dynasty, siding with Wenceslas IV. For his loyalty, the king rewarded him with the village of Horky and the castle of Skalitz near Kostelec in Bohemia.</paragraph><paragraph>In 1404, Jan fought against Sigismund of Luxembourg at Znojmo. As a member of Wenceslas's retinue, he met Jan Zizka in 1409 and went into battle against the Rosenbergs with him. He fought in the Battle of Grunwald, where he sided with the Polish-Lithuanian coalition. After the battle, he was likely poisoned at a feast at the court of Polish King Władysław Jagiełło.</paragraph><years>约1355年 – 1410年9月28日</years><paragraph>兰伯格的约翰·索科尔，是金尼斯的雅罗斯洛夫之子， 拉德季·科比拉之友，也是摩拉维亚的督军。</paragraph><paragraph>他是卢森堡王朝内乱中的关键人物，也是支持瓦茨拉夫的一员。得救后的国王为表彰其忠诚，当即将波希米亚境内的霍基村，以及科思泰莱茨附近的斯卡里茨城堡赏给了索科尔。</paragraph><paragraph>1404年，扬与卢森堡的西格斯蒙德在兹诺伊莫交战。作为瓦茨拉夫的盟友，他于1409年联合扬·杰式卡抗击罗森堡。他加入波兰与立陶宛联军，参加了格伦瓦尔德战役。战役之后，波兰国王弗拉迪斯拉夫·雅盖隆，疑似在一场宴会上对约翰下了毒。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_kralovska_mincovna<paragraph>Originally, it was a fortified castle from the 13th century overseeing the safety of miners and the storage of mined material. However, over time the character of the building changed and instead of a fortress, it began to perform a more lavish and representative function, although it was still the best guarded place in Kuttenberg.</paragraph><paragraph>Massive reconstruction began under Wenceslas II, who centralised the production of coins, until now scattered throughout the kingdom, and started the minting of the <accent>Prague groschen</accent>, which was initially helped by the famous Mint Masters from Florence (the north of Italy was called 'Vlachy', hence the 'Vlašský Dvůr'). The court thus became the equivalent of a central bank.</paragraph><paragraph>Under Wenceslas IV, the mint underwent massive palace-style rebuilding and a chapel was added, but its purpose and exclusivity in terms of producing 'hard currency' remained. From the very beginning, high-quality coins of up to 94% pure silver content were minted here and quickly became a European stable currency.</paragraph><paragraph>Today, 'Vlašský dvůr' is registered as a National Cultural Monument of the Czech Republic and houses a museum. The rich wall paintings of the court no longer exist, nor are there any preserved originals. This detail is rather, artistic license on our part.</paragraph><paragraph>最初，这座建筑是个严加设防的城堡，在13世纪时用于保障矿工安全与存储开采物料。但是后来该建筑的用途发生了变化，尽管它仍是库滕堡戒备最森严的地方，但它却不再用作堡垒，而是开始承担起了更为重要且具代表性的用途。</paragraph><paragraph>瓦茨拉夫二世统治时期，大规模的重建开始兴起，瓦茨拉夫二世还将散布在王国各地的钱币集中起来，着手铸造钱币，也就是<accent>布拉格格罗申</accent>。起初，铸币工作在佛罗伦萨（意大利北部被称为“Vlachy”，因此得名“Vlasský Dvur”）铸币大师的协助下展开，于是皇家宫廷就相当于成为了一个中央银行。</paragraph><paragraph>在瓦茨拉夫四世执政期间，铸币厂进行了大规模的宫廷式改建，并增建了一座小教堂，但其生产“硬币”的功能和独特性得以保留。含银量高达94%的高质量硬币起初便从此处铸造而出，并迅速成为了欧洲稳定的流通货币。</paragraph><paragraph>如今，“意大利宫”（Vlasský dvur）被列为捷克共和国的国家文化古迹，并设有一座博物馆。宫廷里的丰富壁画已不复存在，原作也没有留存下来。游戏中所展示的相关细节更多源自于我们的创作灵感。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_kroniky<paragraph>Since ancient times, educated members of the court or clergy dedicated themselves to writing chronicles, i.e. literary works describing contemporary events, the lives of rulers, great battles, and sometimes everyday life..</paragraph><paragraph>These records were kept chronologically and, beyond the mere dates, they provide a rich source of period information. Chronicles are one of the best sources for studying and reconstructing the history of a country, notable figures, places, buildings, and general realities of the time.</paragraph><paragraph>There are different <accent>types of chronicles</accent>: world, national, episcopal, monastic, royal, dynastic, provincial (tracking genealogy), urban, biographical or autobiographical, travel journals and more.</paragraph><paragraph>Among the most significant Czech chronicles are those of <italic>Cosmas</italic> and <italic>Dalimil</italic>, the Canon of Vyšehrad, the writings of the Sasau Monk and the <italic>Zbraslav Chronicle</italic>. The chroniclers generally enjoyed the most favourable conditions – most lived at courts, had free access to older written records and court life, and ample time devoted solely to writing.</paragraph><paragraph>Although chronicles are the most valuable historic sources, it is important to consider their <accent>historical ideological subtext</accent> when reading and reconstructing them: for example, Cosmas wrote his chronicle with unabashed sympathy for the Přemyslid dynasty, while Dalimil showed great antipathy against the Germans. Both occasionally mixed facts with myths and legends (e.g. the beginning of Czech history with the building of the Tower of Babel).</paragraph><paragraph>Some of the books to be found in the game are a transliterations of chapters from Cosmas or Dalimil - e.g. the account of forefather Čech, the Maidens' War and others.</paragraph><paragraph>自古以来，宫廷或教会的受教育成员致力于撰写编年史。这类文学作品记录了时事、统治者生活、重大战役，有时还包括日常琐事。</paragraph><paragraph>这些记录按时间顺序编写，除了准确的日期外，还提供了丰富的时代信息，因此编年史是研究和重建国家历史、著名人物、地点、建筑和当时社会状况的最佳资料之一。</paragraph><paragraph><accent>编年史的体裁</accent>有很多种，包括：世界编年史、国家编年史、主教编年史、修道院编年史、皇家编年史、王朝编年史、省级编年史（家谱）、城市编年史、传记或自传编年史、旅行日记等。 </paragraph><paragraph>捷克编年史中，比较重要的有<italic>科斯马斯</italic>和<italic>达利米尔</italic>的编年史、维谢赫拉德教士编年史、莎邵修士的著作和<italic>兹布拉斯拉夫</italic>编年史。编年史作者通常享有优越的条件，他们大多生活在宫廷，可以自由查阅文献、参与宫廷生活，并有充足的时间专注于写作。</paragraph><paragraph>尽管编年史是极为珍贵的历史资料，但在阅读和重构它们时，要考虑到作者<accent>历史意识形态</accent>倾向。例如，科斯马斯在撰写他的著作时毫不掩饰对普热米斯尔王朝的同情，而达利米尔则表现出对日耳曼人的强烈敌意。两者偶尔会将事实与神话和传说混合在一起（例如，将捷克历史的开端与巴别塔的传说结合起来）。</paragraph><paragraph>游戏中的一些书籍是科斯马斯或达利米尔章节选译，比如《捷克人的祖先》和《女子战争》等。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_kumani_v_cechach<paragraph>The Cumans (also known as Kunok in Hungary) were a nomadic people belonging to the larger group of Kipchaks (Polovtsians) from the Middle East, who came to Europe in the 13th century, fleeing from the expanding Mongol Empire in the area of the Black Sea.</paragraph><paragraph>They settled in Hungary with the permission of King Béla IV, where they later acquired their autonomous region called Cumania. Gradually, they assimilated with the local population: adopting Christianity, marrying Hungarians, and fighting alongside Hungarian kings, including in wars against the Bohemian Přemyslids.</paragraph><paragraph>They last invaded the Czech lands with Sigismund of Luxembourg, who could not afford better mercenaries than the Cumans. Estimates speak of several thousand warriors. Their army's rampage led to the destruction of places like Silver Skalitz, the birthplace of the main character in our game.</paragraph><paragraph>库曼人（在匈牙利又被称作库诺克人）是基普恰克人（波洛韦茨人）旁支的一支游牧民族，来自中东地区。13世纪时，他们因逃离黑海地区扩张的蒙古帝国而来到欧洲。</paragraph><paragraph>他们得到了当时的匈牙利国王贝拉四世的允许，定居在了匈牙利，并获得了一片名为库曼尼亚的自治区域。后来，他们与当地人口逐渐同化，接受了基督教的教会，与匈牙利人通婚，并在战争中与匈牙利国王并肩作战，对抗波希米亚的普热米斯尔家族。</paragraph><paragraph>在我们的故事开始之前，约有几千的库曼人跟随卢森堡的西格斯蒙德作为雇佣军一起入侵了捷克地区，他们在四处肆虐，摧毁了许多城镇，其中包括盛产银矿的斯卡里茨，也就是我们主人公的出生地。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_literature<paragraph>At the turn of the 14th and 15th centuries, both Czech and German were spoken in the Czech lands.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>German</accent> appeared after German colonisation and spread mainly to towns, higher social strata, love poetry, and bureaucratic language. <accent>Czech</accent> developed from Old Church Slavonic and was used by poorer inhabitants, becoming the official language only during the reign of Charles IV.</paragraph><paragraph>In addition to these two languages, <accent>Latin</accent> was also present, used for writing books, chronicles, scholarly treatises, official documents, and records. Latin was the ecclesiastical and biblical language and served as an international means of communication.</paragraph><paragraph>From the early Middle Ages, monasteries such as Sasau cared for the development and emancipation of the Slavic language. A pioneer in the cultivation of the Czech language in our region was Jan Hus.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Czech literature</accent>became fully established from the early 14th century in various genres: spiritual and secular lyrics (love poetry), epic poetry and plays. The oldest examples of prose included legends, e.g. about Judas, Pilate, the lives of saints, as well as chivalric epics, chronicles and satires. Besides official documents in Latin, letters were written in Czech from the late 14th century.</paragraph><paragraph>在14世纪末及15世纪初，捷克地区同时使用捷克语和德语。德语是在德国殖民后引入的，主要流行于城镇居民、上层阶级、文学领域（比如情诗）和政府公文。而捷克语源自古斯拉夫语，主要由较贫困的居民使用，直到查理四世统治期间才成为官方语言。</paragraph><paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_lorec<paragraph>Whether Loretz was already standing at the time of our game is not clear, as the first written mention of it dates back to 1418.</paragraph><paragraph>It's unlikely that vineyards surrounded the fortress, as they were still a hot novelty in the Lands of the Bohemian Crown at that time, but beer was brewed there. From sources dating back to 1544, we learn that Zdislav Zvířetický of Wartenberg bought the local hop farm with malt house and brewery. In 1593, the production of beer called Kumperské was documented, in 1680 Konvent beer, from 1899 it was Dačický lager and the 'health beer' Mincmistr.</paragraph><paragraph>Loretz Municipal Brewery in Kuttenberg has changed owners several times during its history, but beer has been brewed here, with minor interruptions, to this day.</paragraph><paragraph>在游戏所处的时代背景下，洛雷兹是否已经存在无从考证，因为它于1418年才首次在记录中被提及。</paragraph><paragraph>堡垒周围不太可能设有葡萄园，因为当时在波希米亚王冠领地内，葡萄酒仍然是炙手可热的新奇事物，但是那里的人们会酿造啤酒。根据1544年的史料得知，瓦滕贝格的兹迪斯拉夫·兹维日雷茨基（Zdislav Zvíretický of Wartenberg）购买了当地的啤酒花农场，以及那里的麦芽厂和酿酒厂。1593年，有文献记载了一种名为“Kumperské”的啤酒，1680年则有与一款名为“Konvent”的啤酒的相关记录，到了1899年开始出现“Dacický”拉格啤酒以及“健康啤酒”-“Mincmistr”的有关记录。</paragraph><paragraph>库滕堡的洛雷兹市立酿酒厂在历史上多次易主，但时至今日依然坚持着啤酒酿造工作，只有少数时候有所中断。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_loupeze<paragraph>Thievery and banditry were 'dishonourable professions', whose practitioners were often known in the wider area - that is, if they could evade justice long enough.</paragraph><paragraph>Petty theft most often happened in villages, town markets or taverns. In short, where thieves could hide in the crowd. But people were in greater danger in the open countryside, outside their settlements, or in remote villages, where victims could rarely call for help. Bandits therefore often threatened merchants and travellers on the road, especially around the richer towns, where they flocked to do business.</paragraph><paragraph>Some <accent>bands of robbers</accent> were organised and operated under the auspices of rebelious nobles who profited from their actions. At times they even resorted to raiding entire villages or towns. They would then sell off their loot in markets or taverns.</paragraph><paragraph>The execution books give us evidence of the fate of those, who became involved with bandits. In one of them, we read about Jan Zizka, that: <italic>'He steals herrings and killed a hired hand of the Rosenberg's.'</italic></paragraph><paragraph>偷盗是一种“不光彩”的职业，精通此道的人也会臭名远扬——如果他们还未落入法网的话。</paragraph><paragraph>偷盗常发生在村中、市场或是酒馆内，简单地说，人群中可能随时藏着小偷。但是，在旷野荒山或是偏远村庄这种人烟罕至的地方，人们可能所面临的境况更为险恶。这种地方的强盗们常常会胁迫路过的商人或旅客，在繁华且有活跃市场的城镇周边这种现象尤为突出。</paragraph><paragraph>一些<accent>强盗团伙</accent>接受着反叛贵族们的资助，并在他们的组织与运作下，通过恶行为他们谋利。有时候，他们还会洗劫整座村庄或城镇，事后再到市场或酒馆内进行销赃。</paragraph><paragraph>与处决有关的记录向我们揭露了那些与强盗有染之人的命运，在其中，我们还读到了与扬·杰式卡有关的信息：<italic>“他偷走鲱鱼，并杀死了罗森堡的一位雇工。”</italic></paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_lumberjack<paragraph>In the early Middle Ages, agriculture and the rapid growth of towns required extensive deforestation. Reforestation was not yet being done, so by the 15th century, some areas had even fewer forests than today, and the regions around towns were completely devastated.</paragraph><paragraph>Logging was done by <italic>woodcutters</italic>. The primary tool was a large single-sided axe on a long handle or haft; while various wooden wedges and hammers were used to split the lumber.</paragraph><paragraph>Transport of lumber from distant areas was difficult, which led to using navigable waterways, down which the lumber was left to drift freely.</paragraph><paragraph>中世纪早期时，农业的发展和城镇的快速扩张毁掉了大面积的森林。那个年代还没有植树造林的概念，因此15世纪时有些地方的森林覆盖率甚至比现在还低，有些城镇周边的森林甚至被完全破坏了。</paragraph><paragraph>采伐由伐木工完成，他们的基本工具是长柄的单面大斧和用来切分木材的木质楔子和锤子。</paragraph><paragraph>远距离运输木材很困难，这也促使了通航水路的发展，因为木材在水上可以轻松漂流而下。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_malesov<paragraph>The name of the village is derived from the legend of a wealthy Kuttenberg burgher named Malesh (Maleš), who founded a woodcutter colony here to supply the nearby silver mountains with charcoal.</paragraph><paragraph>The first mention of the village dates back to 1303. The fortress is first mentioned in 1359, when Purkard of Maidberk sold his village to the Sedletz Monastery which subsequently passed the village onto the Ruthards, a patrician family from Kuttenberg, in 1364. When the family was enobled in the early 15th century, they began to call themselves the Ruthards of Maleshov. They did not enjoy the fortress for long, however, because in 1411 it was given to the king's supporter, Martin Kladný of Těchlovice.</paragraph><paragraph>The area around Maleshov is steeped in history. For example, in 1421, Martin Kladný defended the fortress against an army of Praguers, that wanted to install its own Mint Master in Kuttenberg. Maleshov became an important fortress especially during the Hussite Wars in 1424.</paragraph><paragraph>Today, the remains of the fortress include a five-story tower with Gothic windows and remnants of late Gothic fortifications making it a favourite destination for the Warhorse team.</paragraph><paragraph>这座村庄的名字源自一则传说，据说库滕堡有位名叫马莱什（Males）的富有市民，曾在这里建立了一处伐木工人营地，以给附近的银矿山输送木炭。</paragraph><paragraph>关于此村庄的首次提及可追溯至1303年，而堡垒的首次记录则出现在1359年，当时梅德贝克的普卡德将他的村庄卖给了塞德莱茨修道院。1364年，修道院又将村庄转让给了库滕堡的贵族，即鲁瑟德家族。这个家族于15世纪早期被封为贵族后，他们便开始自称“马列索夫的鲁瑟德”。他们没能坐拥那座堡垒太久，14111年，堡垒被转交给了国王的支持者，即特赫洛维采的马丁·克拉德尼（Martin Kladný of Těchlovice）。</paragraph><paragraph>马列索夫周边地区历史悠久。1421年，马丁·克拉德尼抵御了布拉格人对堡垒的袭击，后者想在库滕堡安插自己的铸币官。尤其在1424年发生的胡斯战争期间，马列索夫还成为了一座极具意义的堡垒。</paragraph><paragraph>如今，堡垒的遗迹还剩一座装有哥特式窗户的五层塔楼，以及一些晚期哥特式防御工事的残余部分，那里也是Warhorse团队尤为喜爱的探访之地。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_miskovice<paragraph>The first mention of the village can be found in 1309, when it belonged to Nechval and Peškov of Miskowitz. In 1358, part of the village was taken over by the Skalitz monastery. Until 1805, Miskowitz was enclosed by three gates, but it is not known for sure whether there was a wall between them.</paragraph><paragraph>The fortress in the village stood since time immemorial and the first written mention dates back to 1419, when it belonged to a Kuttenberg burgher Vaněk Píšek.</paragraph><paragraph>The area surrounding the village is rich in water and the spring of St. Adalbert, which supplied Kuttenberg in the Middle Ages, can be found here.</paragraph><paragraph>有关此村庄的记载最早可追溯到1309年，当时它属于米斯科维茨的佩斯科夫（Peskov）和涅赫瓦尔（Nechval）。1358年，村庄的一部分由斯卡里茨修道院接管。到了1805年，米斯科维茨被三座城门环绕，但城门间是否有城墙连接，已无从考证。</paragraph><paragraph>村中堡垒自古以来就已存在，首次文字记载可追溯至1419年。堡主是库滕堡市民万涅克·皮塞克（Vaněk Písek）。</paragraph><paragraph>村庄周围地区的水源极为丰富，中世纪时为库滕堡供水的圣阿达尔贝特之泉就位于此地。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_musicians<paragraph>Theatre as we know it today was not widespread in the Middle Ages and was used more for church purposes (passion plays). Art in the high court, on the other hand, was not comprehensible to commoners, so the profession of folk entertainer was established for a variety of purposes.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Minstrels</accent> were seen at fairs and markets; they made the rounds of taverns and were even hired by wealthy merchants or nobles. The minstrel’s repertoire could include singing, playing musical instruments, juggling, staging scenes or narrating humorous stories.</paragraph><paragraph>The themes of their work were mostly light and cheerful, but often included satire or criticism of political conditions, whether coming from the minstrels themselves, or paid for by an employer and tailored to their intentions. Most of the minstrels had no employer, they belonged to the margins of society and had to get by from day to day through alms.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Musicians</accent> enjoyed a bit more respect and besides entertainment, their music could also be used during religious services. Popular medieval instruments included flutes, trumpets, shawms, as well as lutes, harps and drums. Their performances were mostly improvised, but early musical notations also began to appear at this time.</paragraph><paragraph>There were both, professional musicians employed at court or churches and travelling musicians playing in markets and at celebrations. This craft was predominantly pursued by men.</paragraph><paragraph>我们今天所知道的剧院在中世纪其实并不普遍，主要用于教会用途（如受难剧）。另一方面，高贵的宫廷艺术也不为普通人所喜爱，因此为了各种目的，民间艺人的职业得以确立。</paragraph><paragraph><accent>吟游诗人</accent>开始出现在集市和市场上；他们在酒馆里巡回演出，甚至被富商或贵族雇佣。吟游诗人的节目可能包括唱歌、演奏乐器、杂耍、舞台剧或讲述幽默故事。</paragraph><paragraph>他们作品的主题大多是轻松愉快的内容，但也经常是对政治的讽刺或批评，这些政见可能来自吟游诗人自己，也可能是为雇主量身定制的。不过大多数吟游诗人都没有雇主，他们属于社会边缘群体，靠打赏度日。</paragraph><paragraph><accent>音乐家</accent>则享有更多的尊重，除了娱乐，他们的音乐还可以用于宗教仪式中。中世纪最流行的乐器是长笛、小号、肖姆笛、鲁特琴、竖琴和鼓。他们的音乐作品大多是即兴创作的，不过最早的乐谱也出自这一时期。</paragraph><paragraph>宫廷或教会会雇佣职业的音乐家，而未受雇佣的流浪音乐家则会在市场和庆典上演奏，绝大多数的音乐家都是男性。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_nebakov<paragraph>The castle was likely built at the end of the 13th century on a promontory overlooking Nebak pond, surrounded on all sides by steep cliffs and water. To construct the fortress, the rock beneath it had to be manually hewn away and levelled, which was a relatively complex process for its time, given it was a small noble castle of little significance.</paragraph><paragraph>According to archaeological research, it had a three-part layout with a courtyard and a fortified keep, connected to other parts of the complex by a bridge spanning a rocky moat.</paragraph><paragraph>The first mention of the castle in historical sources only appears in 1455. The castle burned down at the end of the 15th century and from 1538 is described as abandoned and in ruins. The ramparts, moats and notches in the rock are all that remain of the fortifications today.</paragraph><paragraph>We endeavoured to reconstruct the castle in the game in an appearance that aligns as much as possible with archaeological findings.</paragraph><paragraph>这座城堡大概建于13世纪末，位于能够俯瞰内巴科夫池塘的一处海角上，四面还环绕着陡峭的悬崖和水域。要建造这座堡垒，人们必须手工凿除并铲平其下的岩石，考虑到它不过是座名不见经传的小贵族城堡，这个建造过程略显复杂。</paragraph><paragraph>根据考古研究得知，这座城堡的布局分为三部分，其中包括一个庭院和一座设防的主堡，一座跨越岩石护城河的桥梁将其与其它布局连接到了一起。</paragraph><paragraph>这座城堡在史料中的首次提及出现在1455年。该城堡于15世纪末烧毁，自1538年起被认为已遭废弃。如今，城堡仅保留了城墙、护城河和岩石上的壕沟这些防御工事。</paragraph><paragraph>我们尽力在游戏中重现该城堡的样貌，以使其外观尽可能与考古发现保持一致。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_opatovice<paragraph>As the name suggests, the village probably owes its foundation to the abbots (opati) of the nearby Sedletz Monastery, who from the 13th century tried to colonise this inhospitable and sparsely populated region. The first written mention of the village dates back to the latter half of the 14th century, when it belonged to the Kuttenberg burgher Jan Glenc.</paragraph><paragraph>The farmstead of Opatowitz was founded sometime during the 14th century by the monastery, which subsequently supported it until it was sold to another wealthy Kuttenberg burgher, Wenceslas Bartosch (Václav Bartoš), in 1379.</paragraph><paragraph>正如其名所示，这座村庄的建立或许得归功于附近塞德莱茨修道院的院长们（opati），自13世纪以来，他们曾试图在这荒无人烟的不毛之地上殖民。该村庄首次于书中有所提及可追溯至14世纪下半叶，当时它属于名为扬·格伦茨的库滕堡市民。</paragraph><paragraph>14世纪期间，修道院还建造了奥帕托维茨农庄，并对其经营发展施以支持，一直到农庄于1379年专卖给了一位富有的库滕堡市民，此人名叫瓦茨拉夫·巴托什（Václav Bartos）。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_pilgrimage<paragraph>Religious pilgrimages were an important part of the Christian world. There were many reasons to embark on a pilgrimage: seeking forgiveness for sins, shortening the stay in purgatory for the pilgrim's soul or that of their loved ones, asking for healing or other divine help, expressing gratitude, or deepening one's piety and devotion.</paragraph><paragraph>The destinations of pilgrimages were places associated with Christ's presence and activities or the places of action or rest of saints.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>The most significant place</accent> was the city of Jerusalem and the site of the Holy Sepulchre. In Europe, the most visited places included Rome, the seat of the popes and associated with the activities of St. Peter, and the city of Santiago de Compostela with the relics of St. James. In the Czech lands, the most important pilgrimage site was Prague, where the relics of several saints rested over time, the most significant being the national patron St. Wenceslas, who was interred in St. Vitus Cathedral.</paragraph><paragraph>Undertaking a pilgrimage meant enduring a challenging and often dangerous journey, whether by land or partially by sea, and it was considered a significant achievement for the individual. Providing shelter and help to a pilgrim was regarded as a matter of good manners. The development of pilgrimage also had a commercial aspect, especially around pilgrimage sites and travel inns.</paragraph><paragraph>A <accent>pilgrim</accent> could often be recognized by their <accent>specific attire</accent>, which is frequently depicted in various images. This typically included a satchel, cloak, pilgrim's staff, pilgrim badges, and the scallop shell of St. James was a common motif or symbol. The scallop shell was a popular item, believed to be blessed and thus endowed with supernatural abilities. Such a shell was sometimes placed at the bottom of a well to ensure the purity of the water.</paragraph><paragraph>宗教朝圣是基督教世界的重要部分。人们进行朝圣的原因众多：寻求罪孽的宽恕；为朝圣者自身或是亲人的灵魂祈求缩短待在炼狱中的时间；寻求治愈或渴求其它神圣的帮助；传达感激之情，或是深化个人虔诚与敬神之心。</paragraph><paragraph>朝圣的目的地通常是与基督的存在或活动有关的地方，或是圣人活动或休憩之地。</paragraph><paragraph><accent>最具意义的朝圣地</accent>即是耶路撒冷和圣墓遗址。在欧洲，罗马是最受欢迎的地点之一，毕竟它是教皇的所在地，且与圣彼得的活动有关，除了罗马，还有圣雅各布遗物的存放地——圣地亚哥-德-孔波斯特拉。而在捷克地区，最重要的朝圣地则是布拉格，那里安放着多为圣人的遗物，其中最具代表性的就是国家守护者圣瓦茨拉夫，他的遗体就安葬在圣维特大教堂之中。</paragraph><paragraph>踏上朝圣的旅途即意味着要经历一段充满挑战且危险重重的旅程，无论是踏过陆地还是途径海洋，人们都会将其视作重大成就。而为朝圣者提供住所和帮助则会被视作一种礼仪。朝圣活动的发展也会牵动经济和商贸领域的发展，尤其会影响朝圣之地周边以及旅店行业的发展。</paragraph><paragraph><accent>朝圣者</accent>通常可通过其<accent>独特的衣装</accent>来辨认，他们的着装也频繁出现于各类图示中。典型的朝圣服装包括斜挎包、斗篷、朝圣手杖、朝圣徽章，此外，圣雅各布的扇贝壳图案也是常见于朝圣者身上的特征。圣雅各布的扇贝壳是种广受欢迎的物品，被认为受到祝福，因此具有超自然能量。有时候，人们会将此类贝壳放置井底，以确保水的纯净。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_platner<paragraph>The medieval <accent>armourer</accent> made armour from metal plates or sheets – cuirasses, leg and arm protection, helmets, and gauntlets. A specialist in chainmail was called a <accent>maille smith</accent>, and in practice, equipping a heavily armoured soldier required both. Chainmail was worn underneath, with plating on top.</paragraph><paragraph>An ordinary soldier used only parts of the armour (cuirass, helmet, and gauntlets), as few could afford full armour. Decorated or custom-made armour was the privilege of the wealthy nobility.</paragraph><paragraph>Armourers were assisted by <accent>polishers</accent>, who polished and buffed the armour.</paragraph><paragraph>中世纪的铠甲匠使用金属板或金属片制作铠甲，包括胸甲，腿甲，臂甲，头盔和铁手套。专门制作链甲的匠人被称为锁甲匠，而一副完整的铠甲由两部分组成——链甲作为内衬，板甲覆盖在外侧。</paragraph><paragraph>普通士兵只会装备一部分铠甲，通常是胸甲，头盔和手套，因为一整套铠甲的费用超出了他们的承受能力。</paragraph><paragraph>精美的定制铠甲是富庶贵族的专属。板甲匠在制造板甲时有抛光工协助工作，他们负责抛光和打磨铠甲。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_polsko<paragraph>In Poland at the turn of the 14th and 15th centuries, similar to the Czech lands, wars over governance, territory, and faith were occurring. The country's prosperity and its cultural and economic growth were particularly hampered by the relentless attacks of the Teutonic Knights from the so-called Crusader states on northern Polish territories, justified by the need for Christianization and the suppression of the still dominant paganism in the Baltic region.</paragraph><paragraph>Unfortunately, Poland was not unified for long, because after the death of Casimir III the Great, the Piast dynasty, which had long unified and ruled the country, ended in the male line. The crown was taken by Casimir's cousin, Ludwig I of Anjou, the King of Hungary, but he struggled to gain the obedience of the Polish nobility, and his rule and ability to unite a larger coalition against the Crusader invasion were thus very limited.</paragraph><paragraph>The most suitable solution eventually was the marriage of Ludwig's daughter Hedwig to Jagell, the Grand Duke of Lithuania. He took the name Vladislav, was accepted as the King of Poland, and, along with the rest of Lithuania, was baptized. This created the Polish-Lithuanian coalition, which significantly weakened the Teutonic Order.</paragraph><paragraph>However, the Crusaders did not want to give up so easily, and the war continued for many more years. A turning point in this conflict was the Battle of Grunwald in 1410, in which the Teutonic forces were decisively defeated by the Polish-Lithuanian army. Many Czech fighters fought on the side of the Poles at that time, including Jan Zizka and Jan Sokol of Lamberg.</paragraph><paragraph>在14至15世纪之交的波兰领土上，与捷克大陆类似，人们为了争夺控制权、领土和信仰而四处引发战火。尤其是波兰北部受到所谓的十字军国家派出的条顿骑士团的不断侵扰，战争冲突阻碍了该国的繁荣以及文化和经济的发展。这些战争被认为是为了对当地进行基督教化，扼杀波罗的海地区主流的异教信仰。</paragraph><paragraph>遗憾的是，波兰未能保持长久的统一。卡西米尔三世驾崩以后，统治多年的一统王朝皮亚斯特于战争中覆灭。后来，卡西米尔的堂兄、匈牙利国王安茹·路易一世登基，但波兰贵族却不愿向其俯首称臣，因此他在统筹联军抵抗十字军侵略的过程中备受阻碍。</paragraph><paragraph>最好的解决办法就是让路易的女儿海德薇与立陶宛大公雅盖沃联姻。雅盖沃后取名弗拉迪斯拉夫，登上波兰王位，与立陶宛众人一同受洗，波兰-立陶宛联盟因此结成，进而削弱了条顿骑士团的影响力。</paragraph><paragraph>然而，十字军并不会轻易投降，战争也因此持续多年。战争的转折点是发生于1410年的格伦瓦尔德战役，波兰-立陶宛联军在这场战役中迎头击败了十字军。当时许多捷克战士也为波兰出战，其中就包括扬·杰式卡和扬·索科尔。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_pranyr<paragraph>The pillory was located in the middle of the square and was used to administer minor punishments for offenses such as perjury, slander, or fraud.</paragraph><paragraph>It was most often a wooden or stone column to which the condemned were chained for a certain period (hours or even days). The punishment was then carried out by the entire community – spitting, insults, mockery, and the occasional blow were common.</paragraph><paragraph>颈手枷就设在在广场的中央。如果犯人犯了轻罪，比如伪证造假，诽谤或者各种欺骗罪，都会在这里受到惩罚。</paragraph><paragraph>颈手枷可为木墩或者石墩，犯人会被锁在上面以示众一段时间（几个小时，甚至几天）。犯人还会受到整个村镇的责罚——整日迎接人们的唾沫、谩骂、嘲讽，或是被随机投掷而来的物品打中。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_pritoky<paragraph>The first written mention of the village Pschitoky dates back to 1141, according to which it was in possession of the Olomouc archdiocese. In 1249, Pschitoky was briefly held by Havel of Löwenberk, and a year later the Olomouc bishop Bruno of Schauenberk ceded the village to the Sedletz Monastery.</paragraph><paragraph>In the 14th century, the farmstead and part of the village belonged to various patrician families from Kuttenberg, such as Ondřej Puša, under whom a Gothic fortress was added. In 1397, Wenceslas Bartosch (Václav Bartoš) became the owner, and pledged to pay a permanent fee to the Kuttenberg almshouse from the farmstead.</paragraph><paragraph>After the Hussite Wars, Hanush Ferydan held Pschitoky, burdening the farmstead and fortress with many debts which he refused to pay, so in 1443 the chief Mint Master decided that Hanush and his descendants 'from now and for all time' had to pay 50 dozen groschen to the Kuttenberg almshouse every year. The last burgher to own Pschitoky was Voršila Cihelníková, who sold the estate to Václav Materna of Květnice in 1501. The Maternas rebuilt the Gothic fortress in the Renaissance style.</paragraph><paragraph>To this day, only the Gothic vaulted cellar remains, though in a very poor condition.</paragraph><paragraph>关于普西托克村庄的首次书面记载可追溯至1141年，据悉，当时这座村庄正归奥洛穆茨大教区所有。1249年，普西托克村庄曾由洛文博克（Löwenberk）的哈维尔短暂持有，一年后，奥洛穆茨主教布鲁诺将该村转让给了塞德莱茨修道院。</paragraph><paragraph>14世纪时，村庄的部分区域与其农庄由库滕堡的各大贵族持有，其中就包括欧帝·浦沙（Ondrej Pusa），在此家族治理期间，他们还在村中增建了一座哥特式堡垒。1397年，瓦斯拉夫·巴托什（Václav Bartos）成为了村庄的所有者，此人还发誓将利用农舍所得，永久资助库滕堡的救济院。</paragraph><paragraph>胡斯战争之后，普西托克归瀚纳什·费尔丹所有，但此人却让农庄和堡垒负债累累，还拒绝偿还。因此，1443年，首席铸币官决定让瀚纳什及其子孙“世世代代”每年都要向库滕堡救济院支付50打格罗申。普西托克村庄的最后一位主人是沃斯拉·西赫尼科瓦（Vorsila Cihelníková），此人后于1501年又将村庄转卖给了克维特尼采（Květnice）的瓦斯拉夫·玛特纳（Václav Materna）。玛特纳家族以文艺复兴风格重建了那座哥特式堡垒。</paragraph><paragraph>如今，城堡仅剩哥特式的拱形地下室，而且它的状况十分不堪。</paragraph> There were numerous regulations and laws covering brothels and the ‘oldest profession', as well as a special tax. Laws also covered considerate treatment of prostitutes and protected them from violence.</paragraph><paragraph>在波西米亚，妓院被叫做“hampejz”，“whorehouse”或是“house of shame”，但“brothel”一词很少使用。卖淫者就被叫做“妓女”。</paragraph><paragraph>这一职业也分很多种。最贫困的是无家可归的女人，在大街上提供“服务”。有些妓女会伪装成买面包的，去顾客家里提供服务，还有一些是专为贵族和皇家服务的。另外还有些妓女在妓院里提供服务，价格多样，客人包括镇民、官员和贵族（有时候也完全相反，例如贫民窟里那些干粗活的人）。</paragraph><paragraph>运营妓院的不仅有普通市民，甚至还有宗教领袖或教长（例如威瑟赫拉德南边的圣吉尔斯教堂的教区牧师）。妓院一般都和澡堂有直接联系。</paragraph><paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_rabstejn<paragraph>Rabstein Castle (from German: <italic>'Rabe'</italic> - raven, and <italic>'Stein'</italic> - stone, therefore sometimes also known as Krkavec Castle, Raven's Stone or Crow Stone) was built in the 14th century by Nicolaus Rabenstein, a wealthy burgher from Kuttenberg.</paragraph><paragraph>The settlement likely stood on a promontory above the Vejvanovský stream which flows into the Vrchlitz (Bach) river. A mill called <accent>Rabštejnka</accent> was later built near the castle. Sources mention the castle until its demise in 1455. Local floods often occurred in the vicinity of Vrchlitz river, so today most of the ruins are submerged.</paragraph><paragraph>We know that after Rabenstein's death, the property belonged to other rich families from Kuttenberg: the Rotlevs, after 1416 the Piseks, and then the Lems. For the purposes of our game, however, we have decided to present the site in the form of a romantic ruin.</paragraph><paragraph>拉布斯坦堡建于14世纪，由库滕堡的富裕市民尼古劳斯·拉本施泰因（Nicolaus Rabenstein）建造。名称源自德语，<italic>“Rabe”</italic>意为渡鸦，<italic>“Stein”</italic>意为石头，因此有时也称为克尔卡维茨城堡、渡鸦石堡或乌鸦石堡。</paragraph><paragraph>这座城堡可能位于流入弗赫利茨河的维夫诺夫斯基溪（Vejvanovský stream）之上的一处海角。后来，城堡附近建起了一座名叫<accent>拉布什泰因卡（Rabstejnka）</accent>的磨坊。文献记载，这座城堡于1455年被毁。弗赫利茨河附近洪水泛滥，因此如今城堡的大部分遗迹已被淹没。</paragraph><paragraph>我们了解到，拉本施泰因死后，这座城堡落入了库滕堡其它富裕家族手中：先是罗特拉夫家族持有，1416后归属于皮塞克家族，随后便是由雷姆家族拥有。从游戏需求出发，我们决定将此地设定为一处浪漫动人的遗迹。</paragraph> <years>? - 1416年</years><paragraph>拉德季·科比拉曾是波希米亚的佃农、瓦茨拉夫四世的皇家督军， 在1410年和1415年之间是维谢赫拉德（Vysehrad）的城守。1403年，他在斯卡里茨担任指挥官，负责监管银矿的开采。世人皆知国王常会向低爵位贵族施恩，授予他们高位以换取他们的忠诚。拉德季也许就是被授爵者之一，也有可能是国王的好友。</paragraph><paragraph>1403年，斯卡里茨遭到袭击，西格斯蒙德国王与他麾下的库曼军队将此地烧成灰烬。 瓦茨拉夫四世念其多年的效命和忠诚，允许拉德季在萨扎瓦河畔韦塞利（Veselí nad Sázavou）建造自己的城堡。</paragraph><paragraph>1416年，在教士的煽动下，拉德季在库滕堡的一家酒馆里被一群矿工杀害。“那些人在他们落脚的旅店里挟持了他们，把他们的尸体切成碎片，还把那些尸块扔到街上。他们使劲地踩踏着那些遗骸，嘴里哼着欢快的调子。回到教士家里的他们，等着自己的暴行得到夸奖。”</paragraph><paragraph>此事发生在拉德季为国王收税的过程中。令人惊奇的是，六年前的他可能还是个强盗骑士，至于他是如何重新为国王效力的，尚且无从查证。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_ratbor_tvrz<paragraph>The first written mention of Raborsch appears in 1362. At that time, the adjacent village belonged to Mikuláš Velkuš, a townsman from Kuttenberg, who sold it to Mikuláš Wonderbute between 1386-1389.</paragraph><paragraph>The rapid change of owners is characteristic of the fortress, even to this day: after his death it passed to King Wenceslas IV, from whom it was acquired by another Kuttenberg burgher, Martin Oderin.</paragraph><paragraph>In 1402, the fortress and the village were burnt down by King Sigismund of Hungary during the siege of Kuttenberg. The remains of the fortress continued to change hands during the 15th century until they came under the administration of King George of Podiebrad and from there to the captain of Kolin, Jan Hrabaň, at Přerubnice. The list of subsequent owners is extensive.</paragraph><paragraph>Today the fortress (rebuilt into a castle) is privately owned. Only part of the masonry of the south-east corner and one room with a ribbed vaulting have been preserved from the original Gothic building.</paragraph><paragraph>与拉博施有关的记录首次出现于1362年。当时，附近的村庄属于库滕堡市民米库拉什·韦尔库什（Mikulás Velkus），后在1386年至1389年期间，他将村庄卖给了米库拉什·温德布特（Mikulás Wonderbute）。</paragraph><paragraph>频繁易主贯穿着这座堡垒的一生，即便时至今日仍然如此：温德布特死后，堡垒便由瓦茨拉夫四世国王接管，而后又一位库滕堡市民，马丁·奥德林，从国王手中取得了这座城堡。</paragraph><paragraph>1402年，在库滕堡遭受袭击期间，匈牙利国王西格斯蒙德将村庄焚毁殆尽。村庄的残余部分在15世纪时期再次易主，直至波杰布拉迪的乔治国王将其收至麾下进行管辖，而后又交给了治理普热鲁布尼采（Prerubnice）的科林长官扬·赫拉班（Jan Hraban）。后续该堡垒的持有者仍不断更换。</paragraph><paragraph>如今，这座堡垒（已被改建成一座城堡）归私人所有。该建筑仅有东南角的一部分砖墙和一间带有肋拱的房间仍保持着原有的哥特式风格。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_razba<paragraph>Manual coin minting was a complex process in the Middle Ages.</paragraph><paragraph>After the raw silver was mined and processed, ingots, known as <italic>cans</italic>, were made from the precious metal alloy. The ingots were then hammered into thin, narrow strips by the <accent>minters</accent>, from which squares, so-called <italic>farfule</italic>, were cut with large shears and then rounded. The slices were then hammered into a circular shape on the anvil and then smoothed by a process known as <italic>clipping</italic>.</paragraph><paragraph>Only then could the <accent>coiner</accent>, known as a <italic>pregéř</italic>, step in to insert the coin between two dies at the minting tables and strike it with a hammer. Since great strength was required, the coiner had to be a mountain of a man: one hand was needed to hold the two stamps together, the other to pound them with a heavy hammer. Later on, when thalers replaced Prague groschen, two people were needed for minting.</paragraph><paragraph>The activity was very noisy and had to be well-guarded. Most engravers eventually became partially deaf and were not allowed to wear clothing with loose folds or pockets, which could be used to conceal something.</paragraph><paragraph>Imperfect coins were collected and subsequently melted down to be reminted.</paragraph><paragraph>中世纪手工铸币的过程十分复杂。</paragraph><paragraph>银矿经过开采和加工后，会先和其他金属制成名为<italic>原坯</italic>的合金锭，<accent>铸币工</accent>随后将原坯捶打成薄而窄的条状，并用剪刀将其剪成方形的<italic>“方片”</italic>，并将其修圆。最后，这些圆片将在铁砧上捶打成规整的原型，并通过名为<italic>“修边”</italic>的过程对边缘进行平滑处理。</paragraph><paragraph>到这一步之后，这些钱币将会交由<accent>制币工</accent>（捷克语<accent>pregér</accent>）进行后续处理。他们将钱币夹在两个模具之间，并用锤子敲击。这一工作需要很大的力气，所以制币工必须十分强壮，他们需要能用一只手控制住两边的模具的同时，用另一只手上的重锤完成敲击。后来，塔勒取代了布拉格格罗申，这一过程就需要两个人来完成了。</paragraph><paragraph>铸币过程十分复杂，需要严加看守，而由于过程中巨大的噪音，大多数的工人都会患上不同程度的听力障碍。他们在工作时不允许穿着带有松散褶皱或口袋的衣物，以防藏匿钱币。</paragraph><paragraph>在制作流程中，不合规格的钱币会被集中回收，最后熔化重铸。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_rychta<paragraph>The Town Hall is <accent>the seat of the Bailiff</accent> and <accent>the Council</accent>.</paragraph><paragraph>Originally it was an ordinary town house, gradually transforming into the local government office or Town Hall. In Bohemia the first Town Hall was established at the end of the 14th century.</paragraph><paragraph>The buildings were usually of brick, at least the lower floors, with many rooms having vaulted ceilings. The ground floor of the municipal building hosted shops, a tavern, the site of the public scales, a sentry room and an armoury.</paragraph><paragraph>The room housing the <accent>public scales</accent> (which set the standard for all other scales in shops) had a cubit length measure set in the wall and samples of other small measures and weights, which were universally valid throughout the town's administrative domain.</paragraph><paragraph>On the first floor of the Town Hall was the Council Hall, the chapel (in an oriel), the scribe's study and residential chambers. The upper floors served as a granary or warehouse. In the cellar there was a jail and storage for goods.</paragraph><paragraph>The Council Hall hosted the meetings of the City Council and its cabinets contained documents, deeds, charters, privileges and the town archive.</paragraph><paragraph>市政厅是<accent>执行官</accent>和<accent>议会</accent>的工作场所。</paragraph><paragraph>它起初只是一座普通的城镇住宅，后来慢慢地变成了地方政府办公室或市政厅。波希米亚的第一个市政厅建立于14世纪末。</paragraph><paragraph>这些建筑通常由砖石建成，至少低楼层是如此，其中设有许多带有拱形天花板的房间。市政大楼的底层有商店、酒馆、公用天秤点、岗哨和军械库。</paragraph><paragraph>存放公共天秤的房间（所有商店的天秤都以这个为标准）的墙上都刻了一肘尺的标准长度，以及其它适用于整个城镇行政区域的测量单位和重量标准。</paragraph><paragraph>市政厅的二楼有议会厅、小教堂（在凸窗的位置）、抄写员的书房以及住房。上面几层用作粮仓或仓库。地窖里则有一个监狱和一间货仓。</paragraph><paragraph>议会厅用来主持市议会的会议，议会厅里的大橱柜里则存放着文件、契约、许可证和特权以及城镇档案。 </paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_rytirske_rady<paragraph>The first knightly orders emerged at the end of the 11th century, primarily in connection with the Crusades. They were a combination of religious order and military organization, appealing to Christian values as well as chivalric traditions and service to society. Besides noble knights, the <accent>members of the order</accent> also included a large number of common people: foot soldiers, archers, sailors and auxiliary military professions.</paragraph><paragraph>Becoming a member of a knightly order might have seemed like a suitable career choice for a young medieval man, but often the opposite was true. Life was subject to strict rules and organization, often requiring celibacy, life in a closed convent or long fasts. For example, the <italic>Templars</italic> forbade paying ransom for their members, so falling into enemy hands meant imprisonment or death.</paragraph><paragraph>In the High Middle Ages of the 13th and 14th centuries, the orders underwent their greatest expansion, with their armies numbering tens of thousands of fighters, and in some cases, they even founded their own states (such as in the Baltic region or later in Malta). In more recent history, their religious and ecclesiastical context has faded, and the orders have focused more on charity.</paragraph><paragraph>The most famous knightly orders were the <italic>Templars</italic>, the <italic>Order of St. John</italic> (or Knights of Malta), the <italic>Teutonic Order</italic>, the <italic>Knights of the Holy Sepulchre</italic>, and the <italic>Knights of St. Lazarus</italic>.</paragraph><paragraph>首支骑士团出现在11世纪末，主要与十字军东征有关。他们是宗教团体和军事组织的结合体，具有基督教价值观以及骑士传统和服务社会的理念。除了贵族骑士，<accent>骑士团成员</accent>还包括大量普通人：步兵、弓箭手、水手和辅助军事专员。</paragraph><paragraph>对于年轻的中世纪男性来说，成为骑士团成员看似是个合适的职业选择，但事实往往恰恰相反。骑士的生活受到严格的规则和组织约束，通常要求禁欲、在封闭的修道院生活或长时间禁食。例如，<italic>圣殿骑士团</italic>就禁止为其成员支付赎金，因此落入敌手则意味着只有监禁或死亡。</paragraph><paragraph>在13与14世纪的中世纪鼎盛时期，骑士团历经了规模最为庞大的扩展，其军力可达到数万人，有些骑士团甚至还建立了自己的国家（如波罗的海地区或后来的马耳他）。近代时期，它们的宗教和教会背景逐渐淡化，当时的骑士团则更多地专注于慈善事业。</paragraph><paragraph>最著名的骑士团有<italic>圣殿骑士团</italic>，其次是<italic>圣约翰骑士团</italic>（马耳他骑士团）、<italic>条顿骑士团</italic>、<italic>圣墓骑士团</italic>和<italic>圣拉撒路骑士团</italic>。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_semin<paragraph>Semín (Semine) is a small village lying to the west of Troskowitz. In earlier times, it included a fortress that no longer exists today, which, according to surviving records, belonged to Jan and Oldřich of Semín in the year 1365. These two brothers, and later their children, owned the fortress until 1416, but did not reside there much because they chose other places for their seats. In 1375, Oldřich’s son Jan therefore assumed administration of Semín, and after him it passed to his sons Petr and Přibík.</paragraph><paragraph>Whether these Semín men were ancestors or relatives of the Semín of Semín line – an old Bohemian minor noble family – unfortunately can no longer be definitively proven or disproven. So far, the only discovery is that the first to bear that name was Jakub the Younger Semín of Semín, as late as 1422.</paragraph><paragraph>Even so, we decided to present the owner of the Semín fortress in our game as a representative example of impoverished nobility dwelling in pleasant countryside.</paragraph><paragraph>As for the place where the fortress is situated, the terrain bordered by steep rocky slopes, lakes, marshes and fishponds became an ideal settlement area as early as the middle of the first century BC. Remains of massive ramparts can be found here, the most prominent part being a ten-metre-high frontal rampart with a moat, which archaeological research indicates was built by the Celts.</paragraph><paragraph>In Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2, one also finds the Semín mill, which belonged to the lords of Semín for centuries, and it remains an important part of the picturesque landscape to this day.</paragraph><paragraph>塞米（Semín或Semine）是位于特罗斯科维茨以西的一个小村庄。这里曾有一座堡垒，但如今已荡然无存。根据现有记录，这座堡垒在1365年属于塞米的扬（Jan）和奥尔德里希（Oldrich）两兄弟。这两兄弟及其后代一直拥有这座堡垒，直至1416年。但他们很少在此居住，因为他们在其他地方另有住所。1375年，奥尔德里希的儿子扬（与其叔父同名）接管了塞米的管理，之后又传给了他的儿子彼得（Petr）和普日比克（Pribík）。</paragraph><paragraph>至于塞米的这些领主是否是塞米家族（一个古老的波西米亚小型贵族家族）的先祖或亲属，如今已无从考证。目前唯一能确定的是，最早使用此姓氏的人是1422年的小雅库布·塞米（Jakub the Younger Semín of Semín）。</paragraph><paragraph>尽管如此，我们还是在游戏中将塞米堡垒的主人设定为贫困贵族的代表，展现他们居住在宜人乡村中的生活场景。</paragraph><paragraph>堡垒所在之地，四周被陡峭的岩石坡、湖泊、沼泽和鱼塘所环绕，早在公元前一世纪中期就成为了理想的定居之所。在这里，可以找到大规模防御工事的遗迹，其中最引人注目的是一座十米高的正面防御墙及护城壕沟，考古研究表明这些防御设施是由凯尔特人建造的。</paragraph><paragraph>在《天国：拯救2》中，你还可以找到塞米磨坊。这座磨坊几个世纪以来一直属于塞米领主，如今仍然是这片如画风景中不可或缺的一部分。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_stribskalice<paragraph>The area where Skalitz (Skalice), the birthplace of our hero Henry, is situated today, was probably settled in the 13th century. The development of the town was prompted by silver mining in the area as well as the existence of the nearby parish of Rovná.</paragraph><paragraph>The owners of the castle included Ješek of Skalitz (from 1384) and Bohdal of Drahonice (1402-1403). In 1403, Wenceslas IV took possession of it and placed it under the governance of the knight Sir Radzig Kobyla. However, in the same year, he had to leave the castle in order to save the inhabitants of Skalitz from Sigismund's army, who torched the castle and the adjoining village; the estate was never rebuilt.</paragraph><paragraph>In December of 1403, Wenceslas IV granted the remains of the village to Jan Sokol of Lamberg. The ruins of the medieval castle and its fortifications was scavenged for building material for the Church of St. John of Nepomuk. Today, only a small part of the masonry of the gate, the bailey and the walls remain.</paragraph><paragraph>斯卡里茨，即亨利的家乡，可能在13世纪便有人在此定居。银矿业和附近罗维那（Rovná）教区推动了该地区的城镇发展。 </paragraph><paragraph>城堡的故主包括斯卡里茨的耶舍克（自1384年起）和达荷尼采的波达尔（1402 - 1403）。瓦茨拉夫四世于1403年将其接管，并交由骑士拉德季·科比拉治理。同年，科比拉被迫离开城堡，保护斯卡里茨人民免遭国王西格斯蒙德的军队屠戮。随后，侵略者将城堡及周围的村庄付之一炬，自此城堡再也没有重建。 </paragraph><paragraph>1403年12月，瓦茨拉夫四世将村庄余部让渡给兰贝格的扬·索科尔。这座中世纪城堡的遗迹及其防御工事于1730年被拆除，所得材料用于建造尼波姆克的圣约翰大教堂，只有门楼、瓮城和城墙的一小部分留存至今。</paragraph>
ui_codex_cont_svata_rise_rimska<paragraph>Not only a geographical area of countries following the glory of Rome after its collapse, but also a socio-political power formation with a great symbolic value. It was not a unified state, but a very loose union of many different states. Officially, the empire functioned from 962 until 1806, its size and member states changing frequently. The emperors of the Holy Roman Empire were elected by the so-called prince-electors until the 15th century, when the Habsburg dynasty claimed the imperial throne hereditarily. The coronation of an emperor was accompanied by many political struggles, especially on the part of the Church, which claimed the so-called investiture for itself and wanted to be indispensable in this activity. Thus, each emperor had to accept his title from the hands of the Pope.</paragraph><paragraph>The Bohemian Principality became part of the Empire in the early 11th century, but thanks to Přemysl Otakar I, the Bohemian lands had a special status within the confederation: the Bohemian monarch was exempt from all obligations to the Holy Roman Empire, except for participation in the councils.
